oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Weâ€™ve been doing it all wrong: Working with cattle producers to right the parasite control ship
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Jones, Meredyth
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: beef cattle
Ostertagia
Cooperia
parasites
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Anthelmintic resistance in cattle is a growing concern with widespread resistance reported, especially to the avermectin drugs. Treatment of all animals, use of long-acting products, and lack of seasonally strategic plans have all contributed to the problem, along with other factors. Beef cattle veterinarians and producers should come to terms with this reality and start testing for anthelmintic resistance at the level of production groups. Based on individual herd data, holistic and refugia-based parasite control programs should be developed which include considerations of nutrition, climate, strategic selection of animals for treatment, and pasture management.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2021 Recent Graduate Proceedings ; 43-45
